meta.name: The Elephant Man
meta.description: A Victorian surgeon rescues a heavily disfigured man who is mistreated while scraping a living as a side-show freak. Behind his monstrous façade, there is revealed a person of kindness, intelligence and sophistication.

review.name: i'm speechless
review.reviewBody:
I just watched this movie last night and i must say... it touched me in a way no other movie has... some of the scenes even brought me to tears, which has never happened to me before.... John Hurt and Anthony Hopkins are simple incredible, and this movie is just filled with unforgettable scenes....

 but like some people have mentioned here before, it is an incredibly hard movie to watch, especially after you realize what a sweet, kind, smart and innocent man John Merrick was, it is often painful to watch the way he's treated by some people, and like Hopkins says after he sees him for the first time "I pray to god that he's an idiot", sadly, he is everything but that...

10/10, no question

description.value: In celebration of the 40th anniversary of 'The Elephant Man,' we take a look back at David Lynch's critically-acclaimed film, starring Sir Anthony Hopkins, John Hurt, and Anne Bancroft.

plotText.plainText: A Victorian surgeon rescues a heavily disfigured man who is mistreated while scraping a living as a side-show freak. Behind his monstrous façade, there is revealed a person of kindness, intelligence and sophistication.

originalText.plaidHtml:

10/10, no question

text.plaidHtml: This movie was executive produced by Mel Brooks, who was responsible for hiring writer and director David Lynch, and obtaining permission to film in black-and-white. He deliberately left his name off of the credits, as he knew that people would get the wrong idea about the movie if they saw his name on the movie, given his fame as a satirist.

In the film, Joseph Merrick befriends Dr. Treves before he is kidnapped and taken to Belgium. In real life, Merrick never met Dr. Frederick Treves until he was rescued by police from a train station in London as was shown in the film.

lines.text: I AM NOT AN ELEPHANT! I AM NOT AN ANIMAL! I AM... A HUMAN BEING! I... AM... A... MAN!

text.plaidHtml:
Closing disclaimer:
This has been based upon the true life story of John Merrick, known as The Elephant Man, and not upon the Broadway play of the same title or any other fictional account.

question.plainText: How long is The Elephant Man?

In the beginning of the film, right after John Merrick's mother is being attacked by elephants, we then see smoke/dust rising upward, with a baby wailing in the background. What does that scene suppose to simplify?
Why does Dr. Treves call Merrick an idiot? Isn't that a bit harsh?
Did everything happen to Merrick just like in the film?
